Information: The world's most widely grown cereal. Used primarily for flour (bread, pasta) and livestock feed. A cool-season (Rabi) crop that tolerates frost but requires a dry, warm harvest period. High in gluten protein (bread wheat).
Common Pests: Aphids, Hessian Fly, Cereal Leaf Beetle
Image Description: Golden field of ripening wheat stalks

Information: The staple food for over half the world's population. Paddy rice requires flooded fields for weed control and specific soil conditions. It is a warm-season (Kharif) crop and a major source of global carbohydrates.
Common Pests: Rice Weevil, Rice Blast, Brown Planthopper

Information: Botanically a fruit (berry), consumed as a vegetable. Requires warm, frost-free conditions and is often grown with stakes/cages. Rich in Vitamin C and Lycopene (antioxidant).
Image Description: Ripe red tomatoes hanging on the vine

Information: A starchy root tuber, one of the world's most important staple foods. Prefers cool weather for tuber development. Crop rotation and certified seed tubers are essential for disease control.
Image Description: Harvested potatoes of various colors on the ground

Information: A highly versatile cereal used for human food, animal feed, and ethanol production. Maize is a C4 plant, making it very efficient at using water and sunlight in warm climates.
Common Pests: Maize Stem Borer, Corn Earworm, Rootworm
Image Description: A large corn field with mature yellow cobs

Information: A root vegetable rich in Vitamin A and Beta-Carotene. Requires deep, loose, stone-free sandy loam to prevent root splitting or forking. Thinning seedlings is critical.
Image Description: Bright orange carrots partially pulled from the soil

Information: The world's leading natural fiber crop. The white fluffy fiber (lint) is separated from the seeds (ginning). Seeds provide oil and meal for livestock feed.
Image Description: Fluffy white cotton bolls ready for picking

Information: A major global source of protein and vegetable oil. As a legume, it fixes atmospheric nitrogen into the soil via root nodules, reducing the need for N fertilizer.
Common Pests: Soybean Aphid, Pod Borer, Cyst Nematode
Image Description: Green soybean pods on the plant

Information: A bulb vegetable grown for flavor and rich in sulfur compounds. Requires high levels of light and a long day length for proper bulb formation.
Image Description: Onion bulbs with green shoots in a field

Information: A perennial grass grown for high sugar content in its stalks. The stalks are crushed to extract juice for sugar and ethanol. Ratooning (regrowth after harvest) is common.
Image Description: Tall stalks of sugarcane ready for harvest

Information: A versatile cereal used primarily for malting (beer), animal feed, and some food. Tolerates poorer soils and drought better than wheat.
A highly drought-tolerant grain used for food (flatbreads), feed, and biofuel. Thrives in arid and semi-arid regions where maize and rice fail.
A cool-season crop, primarily grown for human consumption (oatmeal) and livestock feed. High in soluble fiber (beta-glucan).
A resilient, small-seeded grass, highly valued in arid regions for its tolerance to drought and heat. Used for food (flour) and fodder.
A tropical root crop, the third largest source of food carbohydrates globally. Used for tapioca, flour, and starch. Tolerant of poor soils and drought.
A starchy, sweet root tuber rich in Vitamin A. Highly adaptable crop grown in warm climates. Used for food and feed.
A perennial herb grown for its fruit. Requires high humidity and warm temperatures. Used fresh or processed (cooking bananas/plantains).
A major source of protein and essential micronutrients. Fixes nitrogen, improving soil fertility. Grown as dried beans or fresh snap beans.
A leafy vegetable grown for its dense head. Tolerates cool weather and is a good source of Vitamin C and K. Highly versatile in cooking.
Perennial woody vine cultivated for fresh fruit, raisins, juice, and wine. Requires specific pruning and training systems.
Deciduous fruit tree grown for its fruit. Requires a period of winter chill (vernalization) to produce blossoms.
Evergreen tree grown for its fruit (orange). Requires warm, frost-free climates. High in Vitamin C.
The most productive oil crop globally. Oil extracted from the fruit flesh and kernel is used in food and industry. Requires high heat and rainfall.
Tropical palm grown for its water, meat (copra), and oil. Highly salt-tolerant and thrives near coastlines.
The dominant species of coffee, known for fine flavor. Requires high altitudes, cool temperatures, and specific shade conditions.
Evergreen shrub whose young leaves are processed into tea. Requires high rainfall and acidic soil. Plucked regularly.
Tree whose seeds (beans) are processed into cocoa and chocolate. Requires high humidity and shade in the first few years.
Legume grown for its oil and protein-rich seeds. Seeds develop underground (geocarpy). Fixes nitrogen.
Oilseed crop grown for cooking oil and snacks. Extremely hardy and drought-tolerant; its head tracks the sun (heliotropism).
Oilseed crop for cooking oil and biodiesel. Canola is a specific variety bred for low levels of erucic acid and glucosinolates.
Cool-season pulse crop grown for its edible seeds. High in protein and dietary fiber. Fixes nitrogen.
Pulse crop known for its resistance to drought. Used extensively in Middle Eastern and Indian cuisine. Fixes nitrogen.
The most important forage crop worldwide, highly valued for livestock feed. Perennial and excellent at fixing nitrogen.
Tropical fruit with a unique CAM (Crassulacean Acid Metabolism) photosynthesis, allowing it to conserve water.
Tropical fruit tree known for its healthy, high-fat fruit. Requires well-drained soil and is sensitive to frost.
Perennial climbing vine grown for its dried berries, used as a spice. Requires high rainfall and humidity.
Tropical tree cultivated for its latex (sap) used to produce natural rubber. Requires high rainfall and year-round warmth.
A perennial grass grown for high sugar content in its stalks. The stalks are crushed to extract juice for sugar and ethanol. Ratooning (regrowth after harvest) is common.
Image Description: Tall stalks of sugarcane ready for harvest

Information: Oilseed crop for cooking oil and industrial use. Highly drought-tolerant with deep taproots, adapted to dry regions.
Oilseed and spice crop. Grown for edible oil, condiment, and green fodder. Tolerant of moderate frost.
Natural fiber crop used for sacks, bags, and ropes. Requires high rainfall and humidity for fiber extraction (retting).
Dual-purpose crop: grown for fiber (linen) and seed (linseed oil, high in omega-3). Cool-season crop.
Herbaceous plant grown for its rhizome (underground stem), used as a spice and medicine. Requires rich soil and partial shade.
Herbaceous plant grown for its rhizome, used as a spice (Curcumin) and dye. Requires well-distributed rainfall.
Grown for its fruit (chili), used as a spice or vegetable. Rich in Vitamin C and Capsaicin (heat).
A highly drought-tolerant grain used for food (flatbreads), feed, and biofuel. Thrives in arid and semi-arid regions where maize and rice fail.
A cool-season crop, primarily grown for human consumption (oatmeal) and livestock feed. High in soluble fiber (beta-glucan).
A resilient, small-seeded grass, highly valued in arid regions for its tolerance to drought and heat. Used for food (flour) and fodder.
A staple tuber crop in West Africa. Requires staking (support) and deep, fertile soil. High in carbohydrates and starch.
A tropical root crop (corm) used as a staple. Many varieties are grown in flooded conditions similar to rice.
An ancient oilseed crop known for its high oil content and distinct nutty flavor. Used in food, oil, and cosmetics. Drought tolerant.
